I was feeling a deadly mood one day and I was so tired of rubbish. So tired. You know, Daryl Doc Smith wrote his Space Hoppers back in the 30s and 40s. That's a long time ago. And the period form of art, I think, is dead. But I keep seeing certain writers who shall be nameless rehashing old Space Hoppers. I said, oh, I've had enough of this. So I said, why not just put the boot to all the Space Hoppers one time, have fun doing it. And I made internal parodies of everyone I could think of. People accused me of hating Doc Smith. No, I don't like, I love Docs. Like, Roop-Ring Doc Smith. But I just don't, I think the feel is dead. I'd like to put a tombstone over it. Not that you ever can in fiction. There's still going on doing it anyway. But I enjoy myself. The reeds enjoy it. Some, I mean, the two kind of reeds. Some say you're hating Doc Smith. You know, they chase me around. And they say, huh, I feel a whole bunch of them. You know, so there it is. It takes your choice. Okay. I, the series I read before we came here was the To the Stars series. I don't know if that's your name for it or not. Yeah, that's my name. Yeah. I thought, well, I personally thought the covers on the American editions were terrible. I didn't show a damn thing. The guy with the guns. Yes. I kind of liked it because it gave you the first book. Here's this guy and this, he's this Urbane sophisticated man and a man about the world, the rich. And then it's, then the next novel is an adventure novel. And then it kind of is a hybrid third one. And I kind of enjoyed that because you kind of got to show all your facets. Even some humor. A bit, a bit. A Star Wars thing. We were talking about this morning. A touch, a touch here and there. Yeah. That, that book, it comes about, came about, that the trilogy came about through the inability I have to just to take the situation as set. I can, I know what I got the idea from when I was in California on the freeway with my friend Brian, all this. We were in a horrible little English Sprite, which is about eight inches high and two feet wide. And it goes a maximum of 50 miles an hour. And we're trumbling along five lane freeway, California five, great big articulated trucks with trails going by 14 foot high wheels. I'm looking at the bottom of hubcaps, you know, trying to keep the thing going straight. I had a vision of that point of a world where trucks ran forever on and on and on, through around the whole plan. How can we do that? So I had to develop a whole plan and a culture to get them there. And by the time I'd done it and written the book, the editor said, I feel it's incomplete. How did they get there in the first place? And what happened that revolution afterwards? I said, you're right. I got so much plotting in here. I have a whole book before and a book afterwards. So I took the character. He ride this plan for nameless reasons and it ended with the revolution, which is going wrong. So I went back and told you how he got there. Took an earth and I closed the book together in the final one. They came out different. The one middle one was written first. They had to be a different aspect, you know, then the third one, of course, put the first two together. But as you said, I use different things at different times in their high technology and the enjoyment of technology and a little bit of politics. And the first one is some ways like a make room, make room. And so where are we going to go if we don't get a hold of technology and what we can do? If you know, I say the very, the first book is, shows you how rotten Britain will be 500 years from now. The third book, how rotten America will be 500 years from now and all done for good intentions with lack of knowledge of how to go about taking care of helping people. And they're both rotten worlds. So there again, the administrative thing is being shaken. No, this is you. You must get technologies involved. You must do somehow, not guess, you must just somehow do a better job of ruling the world, you know, we're in a technological world and nobody in the British Parliament or the American Senate or legislation knows anything about science. I mean, we are a bunch of ex lawyers and politicians. Politicians have one motivation life. That's to get reelected. Look at the whole Nixon trouble came about because all he wanted to do would be reelected and doesn't care what you do. And that's the wrong thing. I'm not saying I can't see any easy answers to them. Just saying that there are answers. We are now a technology revolution. We now are going into the computer world and no one has consistently thought what will happen to most people. And in a way behind all the adventure stories, there is a consideration of those problems. The character, I almost thought was the strongest character in those, in that trilogy of the first last book was the brother-in-law again. His name escapes me. That's why I had a written name. Yes. The brother-in-law character. Did you have somebody in mind? Not really. A question you ask is the brother-in-law whose name I forget, the hyphen they are named George Barlington Stone or something. If you look closely, let me say I'm not pretending to be subtle. I'm saying that I am subtle. I'm saying if you examine these books, you'll find a couple of levels. The first book plot-wise and character-wise is a tip of the hat, another head to George Orwell's 1984. I even used the word, leader and for pint and they were his thing. They were drinking leaders instead of pints. I used the word, pros. I put the clues in there for you to find. And the brother-in-law character is the same torturer character from Brian O'Brien or Brian was the other fellow. It is the man who knows his evil and is in charge of an evil society. And that's why he's in the first book. But having not killed him off in the first, he has to appear again and then you get what I thought was the only truthful ending, the ambiguous ending to the third one. People hate me for what happened. I said, that's what life is. Science fiction gives you easy answers, but in real life there are no easy answers. That's what I really liked about it. It was not clear-cut. That is life. That is life. Okay, I want to talk to you a little bit then. You've also done a lot of editing. You slandered editors while ago. I slandered editors? That's right. Because having edited a number of pulp magazines and having edited 85 anthologies, I can knock editors. That's not an easy job, is it? It's not a hard job. It's easier than writing. A successful editor who actually doesn't just copy edit, an editor who purchases stories and prints them in the magazine or a book editor, has to have taste that matches the public. The skills attach are very minor. You can learn to copy edit and to correct. Not to correct. Two things good editors have. That is, their taste matches the public enough. What they buy, people will read. They're publishing how it succeeds. Secondly, better editors have editorial taste where they can take and tell a writer how he can improve his book or his short story. That's something that's like a skill like writing. They're not the same skill. Most editors can't write. Most writers can't edit. Just by chance, I haven't fallen into this. I enjoy a certain amount of editing. I think it helps my own writing. There again. I like to refer back to my own work. When I've done a draft of a book, I try very, very hard to step out of the role of author and look at that as an editor who isn't working. This is not common to me. I mean, how many ways, years ago, every good writer has an inborn automatic shit detector. You smell your manuscript. It smells bad. You throw it out. There again. It goes into making an author with a lot of different skills. If they all work, they work. They don't forget it. Apparently, the editor that edited Will Whirls said, hey, you needed beginning and an ending. They did you a service. So editors can. Can. Well, the girl said this. She said, I feel it's not complete. There's more to it. I can't expand it. There's no way. The second book, Will Whirls Complete Into Itself, begins where it has to begin and ends where it has to end. And started me thinking, yeah. So in a sense, good editor point out that. And but normally I would just said, no, it is a success. Succeeds where it is. But then again, I was in financial problems. So by God, I got trilogy here rather than one book. And two years later, I had three books instead of one, which helps. They package them nicely. They go three into one and works very well. Okay, we've talked before you ask the question. Let me see my wife. Yeah.

segments.text: Your first stories and novels didn't appear when they're written.
They didn't appear when you were in your mid-30s or so.
What had you been doing up until that time?
Now, I had a couple of careers.
You know, mine was a draft degeneration.
We all got drafted at 18, you know, right into the Army.
And I spent the next four years in the AOT, the Army Occupation of Texas.
I sent all the Yankees down here to, you know, teach conglomerate school and aerial gunnery.
I went to art school after the war and then spent 10 years as a commercial artist, mostly in comics.
And then graduated into editing, editing comics, editing pulp magazines.
So I had been around professionally in publishing for a good 10 years, which was not a handicap.
I think it helped.
You were involved, from my understanding, in comics and art.
Did this help you later on with science fiction?
Well, it was a two-barrel question, you know.
I always read science fiction.
Now, the science fiction fan, at the time I was seven years old,
and I read this stuff, read before the Army, afterwards, and then I illustrated science fiction.
And through that, I knew all the authors as an artist.
I was Harry the Artist, and I illustrated books for them and magazine.
And I was around writers all the time.
Science fiction writers.
I really didn't care much about writing.
I cared about science fiction.
So when I started stepping sideways out of drawing into editing and writing,
I wrote everything.
I wrote men's adventures, westerns, historical articles.
I did a fine article on the history of Texas about the Battle of Goliath,
which no one remembers but me.
And then I started writing fiction, and I naturally wrote science fiction.
And I naturally sold it, I suppose, because I'd been writing a lot,
been around the arts for a long time.
And if anything, it helped my visual sense.
When you read my stuff, I hope the rear has a physical sense of where they are
and what's happening, and that's it.
Was your first sale to John Campbell?
No, no.
My first sale was to Damon Knight, who I knew as an editor.
He did a magazine called Worlds Beyond.
I was illustrating about half of it.
And the third issue, I illustrated almost all of it,
but I got down the flu and I couldn't draw, but I could type.
I wrote a short story and asked him what I should do with it.
He paid me $100 for it.
It's a good beginning, you know, I thought.
And my agent at the time, Fred Pohl, put an anthology.
Wow, that's the way to start your career.
And it took me years to sell anything after that.
I didn't write much fiction, but very early on,
I think maybe a second or third or fourth sale,
I sent the Stainless Steel Rat story to John Campbell.
He bought it as a novelette.
And after that, my relationship with him was very close.
I see him all the time, work with him, and since collaborate with him.
And all my first five or six novels were done as serials for analog.
And when I say collaborate, I would send John an outline of an idea,
a page or two of a book I'd like to do.
I was thinking about doing, he sent back 18 page letter of what I could do with the book.
He would never tell you to do something.
He just suggested, do you ever think of doing that or that?
And with his help, I developed a lot of tools.
And I was a typical Campbell writer.
I read the magazine, so I was born, I suppose.
And I didn't bend to John's will.
I just wanted to be there as a Campbell writer.
And I really was a typical one for, I said, the first half dozen books
until I had an idea for a book I knew John would not buy,
a book called Bill the Galactic Hero, which I never submitted to him.
And my feelings were right, I'll tell you, years later.
I was in his office and he said, why did you write that book?
What book, John? What Bill the Galactic Hero?
I said, how do you know I wrote it?
He said, I saw it in the subway newsstand and I bought it.
The whole thought of him buying, he didn't get enough of them,
slush pie, he had to go out and buy books.
And I gave him some waffling answer about why I wrote it.
Because it was a direct opposite of everything he believed in and wanted to do.
It was experimental prose, it was anti-military,
he put the boot to fascist, all the good things, you know.
You drew him very well and wrote for him and understood his system.
What is your comment to people that say,
some people think he had a very healthy effect on science fiction,
some people think he would have been better off without it?
John W. Campbell invented modern science fiction.
When he came along, it was just pulp garbage.
He took it and shaped it.
What we see today, John Campbell did.
His personal attitude towards number of things,
engineering wise, politics wise, I disagree with him at the time
and told him so.
But his overall effect in the field, he did what you see today,
John Campbell did.
Perhaps it had been done eventually.
But single handedly, he stepped down from the mount with the tablets
and took this dismal fantasy field
and developed his modern intellectual, intelligent,
scientifically based science fiction.
It's gone a lot different ways since.
I mean now half of science fiction is pure fantasy.
The solid core that he made people do is very, very dim.
But without that core, you wouldn't have modern science fiction.
Your first novel that was published,
first science fiction novel that was published,
I should put it was Death World.
And that's adventure fiction, which is probably what you're noted for.
And Jason Denault was your main character.
How did that evolve?
Did Jason hit you and then the plot?
Or did he just come up with what you were thinking?
Death World does a number of things.
You mentioned the fact that it was adventure science fiction.
Well, don't laugh, but at that time in science fiction,
which was Campbell, which was analog.
If you were a true blue reader,
you read Starling Stories in Trillion Wonder,
because you'd had to wait another three weeks for the next issue of...
Astounding, that's where the action was.
And he had been very cerebral.
He had a whole novel of people talking to each other.
Nothing moving at all, no action.
And I want to do a book that had action part of the plot.
I mean, that's sort of stupid to say now with all the guns blowing heads away.
I mean, that whole gore school and the whole sword and sorcery, sword and butchery.
I mean, action galore, for no reason at all.
But in those days, it was getting dim, I thought.
So I worked out, but I didn't want to do an action plot for action, say.
So I'm a great back plotter, and it says I find a reason to do a book
and then fit a book to the reason.
And the reason I want to have the action, I want to have a realistic.
So I thought it was Superman.
And in this book, you find, if you look at it closely, it's done two or three levels.
The action plots a service.
But there below that is the idea of Superman and Nietzsche talked about.

And I'm very much against Superman, physical Superman.
And if you look in the book, you'll see that if you are so brutalized to be physically a Superman,
your intellectual content is zero.
And I said that in a number of different ways.
And I'm very much against militarism, and that's been there in a number of different ways.
All of it couched in an adventure plot.
And it's up to the reader to read whichever way he wants.
And he'll find a good adventure plot if he wants to find even more about it.
I remember when I first published it, a reader in England came up to me,
and I was looking forward to great return from literate Englishmen about heavily intellectual content.

I saw my friends to read.
Oh, I like it.
You did.

Jason used his knowledge, his experience, and his determination.

He would turn the tables by using this sort of thing.

Not really.
The Death World 2 and 3 came out by happenstance.
It's just that the character was successful.
I want to write another adventure-style book.

you had a problem, you'd have to go along and organize it.

I did that once more.

It worked pretty well.
And I said, and OK, Death World 2, you may think it's about going off

The entire book is about the difference in meaning between ethics and ethos.

I keep repeating over and over through that thing.

A lot of good things happen.
You learn a bit of Esperanto.
But also what science fiction can do, it's a book that takes the study
of a philosophical question or a problem of meaning and meaning.

None get tired of it.
I did a short story for the Ken Memorial volume, which I edited.
And then I did an even shorter story a year or two ago for a games magazine.

And I did a short story to go in the magazine.
The game was designed around the story.
But I feel no desire to.
I mean, I don't have to.
Luckily, at this stage in life, I can write the books I want to write.
And I see nothing there.
I mean, what you see is what you get.
It's complete in the trilogy.
Fine.
End of step sideways and salute and step out.
So it kind of summarized it.
Yes, it was a trilogy.

No, I wrote a book.
After I finished it, I realized I let an ambiguous ending to it in one sense.
A lot of your characters couldn't go on living unless they left that planet.
That thought in mind.
Another planet.
Having finished that, I can see one more story with the same group of characters.
Did that.
And that was the end.

is now a pentology.
I can say that.
Yes.
And then this is this is adventure science fiction, but it's it's satirical.

parody adventure science fiction.
Yeah, right.

It was just that as the old rat says that we have, you know, flesh and blood rats and

Anyone else alive.

Sharing everybody up, you know, and the story begins.

What place does humor have in science fiction?
Very little.
It could have a bigger one.

Editors, for the most part, are dummies.

That is a matter of taste.
You bring an adventure novel in and it will say, yeah, well, Harry's unbetter, but it's moved along.

I'll buy it.
Bring a love story and oh, well, you know, girl gets kissed, you know, it's a little boring, but I'll buy it.
You're bringing a humor novel.
Doesn't laugh.
He does not buy it.
And if they laugh, I've heard them say, I wanted them to reject it was too funny.
They're afraid the readers won't laugh.
So the only way you can sell humor is have a reputation as a humor writer.
And how do you get a humor writer?
You've got to sell a book, but you can't sell it.
It's a catch-tweeting two thing.

I would make each one funny than the one before.

DeGrees?

Was another memorable character.

How do the character...

In science fiction, science fiction is not a character-based form of fiction.
You can have three-dimensional characters in science fiction.
But the idea comes first.
It's an idea fiction.
To form a fiction, we can have the idea as a hero.
The main thing that has that is what you call three-dimensional.
Have the idea for a character who would do these things.
Which means far too often in science fiction, you'll get two-dimensional characters who just act the assigned role of the plot given to the by the author.
And we don't mind reading that.
We really want to read about the action to make good science fiction, viable, interesting, fun science fiction,
when you have to assign the character the role, you must build his character as a character.
That's where the art comes in.
There are two things in all kinds of fictions.
The craft of science fiction, constructing your plot.
The art of science fiction is making your characters three-dimensional.

Bill, go ahead.

We're right.

he showed that there's some things so awful that you have to laugh at them to understand them.

The army is utterly horrible, boring and wasteful.
The military life is boring and wasteful.

Usually I discovered that I had a Korean war veteran come up to me,
he's a combat marine, wouldn't have his face all shut away.

I said, yes, yes.
